column4: 20. Does the paper mention the use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Large Language Models (LLMs) in the context of requirements?

column3: Generating obstacle conditions for requirements completeness
column8: ILP is used to learn obstacle conditions from positive and negative examples generated by model checking. It generalizes from specific traces to produce potential obstacles that could prevent goals from being achieved.

column3: Using Language Models for Enhancing the Completeness of Natural-Language Requirements
column8:
The paper uses BERT's masked language model (MLM) to generate contextualized predictions for masked words in requirements. Specifically:

BERT Base model is used (12 encoder layers, hidden size of 768, ~110 million trainable parameters)
Cased model is employed as previous RE research suggests it's preferred for analyzing requirements
Configured to generate multiple predictions per masked word (optimal number determined to be 15)
Used to predict potentially missing terminology in requirements
column10: J. Devlin, M.-W. Chang, K. Lee, and K. Toutanova, "BERT: Pre-training of deep bidirectional transformers for language understanding," in Proceedings of the 2019 Conference of the North American Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics: Human Language Technologies, Volume 1 (Long and Short Papers), 2019, pp. 4171–4186.

column3: AI-Enabled Automation for Completeness Checking of Privacy Policies
column6: Machine learning classifiers (specifically Support Vector Machines)
column8: Used as part of an ensemble approach with similarity-based and keyword-based classification to identify GDPR-relevant metadata in privacy policy sentences. The classifiers are trained on word embedding features of annotated sentences.

column3: Improving requirements completeness: automated assistance through large language models
column8: Uses BERT's masked language model to generate contextualized predictions for missing words in requirements. These predictions are used to identify potentially missing terminology.
column10: referencing the original BERT paper: Devlin J, Chang M-W, Lee K, Toutanova K (2019) BERT: pre-training of deep bidirectional transformers for language understanding. In: Annual conference of the North American chapter of the association for computational linguistics: human language technologies (NAACL-HLT'19)

column3: Towards Improved Network Security Requirements and Policy: Domain-Specific Completeness Analysis via Topic Modeling
column8: LDA is used to automatically identify topics in a collection of Acceptable Use Policy (AUP) documents. It provides topic loadings for each document, which are used to determine the level of coverage for each topic. This information is then used to assess the completeness of the AUP documents.

column3: PolicyChecker: Analyzing the GDPR Completeness of Mobile Apps' Privacy Policies
column8: Used for constructing the predicate-argument structure of sentences in privacy policies. The model is trained on the Ontonotes 5.0 dataset for the English PropBank SRL task.
column10: Gardner, Matt, et al. "AllenNLP: A Deep Semantic Natural Language Processing Platform." Proceedings of Workshop for NLP Open Source Software (NLP-OSS).

column3: An AI-Assisted Approach for Checking the Completeness of Privacy Policies against GDPR
column6: The tool was validated through a case study on 24 unseen privacy policies. It achieved a precision of 85% and recall of 96% in detecting incompleteness issues.
column8: SVM classifiers are used to predict level-1 and level-2 metadata types in privacy policy sentences. The classifiers are trained on sentence embeddings derived from pre-trained GloVe word vectors.

column3: A Multi-solution Study on GDPR AI-enabled Completeness Checking of DPAs
column8: Pre-trained language model fine-tuned for binary and multi-class classification of DPA sentences
